Apple___Apple_scab.title: Apple — Apple Scab
Apple___Apple_scab.description: Apple scab is a common fungal disease (Venturia inaequalis) that causes dark, velvety spots on leaves and fruit. It reduces fruit quality and, in severe cases, defoliates trees which lowers yield in following seasons.
Apple___Apple_scab.symptoms: Olive-green to dark brown velvety spots on upper leaf surface; circular scabby lesions on fruit; premature leaf drop and distorted growth.
Apple___Apple_scab.prevention: Plant resistant cultivars, remove and destroy fallen leaves and infected fruit in autumn, improve air circulation by pruning, avoid overhead irrigation.
Apple___Apple_scab.remedy: Apply recommended fungicides (e.g., captan or myclobutanil) during green tip to petal fall stages, follow local extension guidance for timing and dosage; practice sanitation and crop rotation.

Apple___Black_rot.title: Apple — Black Rot
Apple___Black_rot.description: Black rot (Botryosphaeria obtusa) affects apple fruit, leaves, and twigs, producing rotted fruit and cankers. It overwinter in mummified fruit and infected wood.
Apple___Black_rot.symptoms: Round, brown to black fruit rot with concentric rings, leaf lesions with orange margins, twig cankers, and mummified fruit remaining on tree.
Apple___Black_rot.prevention: Prune out and destroy infected wood and mummified fruit, maintain tree vigor, improve air circulation, and avoid wounding trees.
Apple___Black_rot.remedy: Apply fungicides during growing season as recommended; remove infected material promptly; use proper sanitation to reduce inoculum.

Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.title: Apple — Cedar-Apple Rust
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.description: Cedar-apple rust is caused by a fungal pathogen (Gymnosporangium) requiring juniper (cedar) as an alternate host. It produces bright orange lesions and can reduce fruit and foliage quality.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.symptoms: Yellow-orange spots on leaves with gelatinous orange spore horns on the underside during wet weather; leaf deformity and premature defoliation.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.prevention: Remove or manage nearby junipers (alternate hosts) if feasible, choose resistant apple varieties, and space trees for good airflow.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.remedy: Apply protectant fungicides at bud break and in early season if disease pressure is high; remove heavily infected leaves and declutter surroundings.

Apple___healthy.title: Apple — Healthy
Apple___healthy.description: No disease detected. Leaves and fruits appear normal and free of visible pathogen symptoms.
Apple___healthy.symptoms: Uniform green leaves without spots or lesions; fruit without scabs or rots.
Apple___healthy.prevention: Maintain good orchard hygiene, regular monitoring, balanced fertilization, and proper irrigation management.
Apple___healthy.remedy: No treatment required—continue routine care and monitoring to prevent new infections.

Blueberry___healthy.title: Blueberry — Healthy
Blueberry___healthy.description: No disease symptoms detected on blueberry plant. Leaves and fruit show normal appearance and vigor.
Blueberry___healthy.symptoms: Uniform leaf color, normal fruit development without lesions or deformities.
Blueberry___healthy.prevention: Ensure proper soil pH (acidic), good drainage, mulching, and routine monitoring.
Blueberry___healthy.remedy: No treatment needed; continue standard cultural care and monitoring.

Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.title: Cherry — Powdery Mildew
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.description: Powdery mildew is a fungal disease producing a white powdery coating on leaves and young shoots. It weakens the plant and can reduce yield and fruit quality.
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.symptoms: White to gray powdery patches on upper leaf surfaces, distorted or curled leaves, and stunted shoots.
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.prevention: Promote air circulation by pruning, avoid dense planting, remove infected tissue, and plant resistant varieties if available.
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.remedy: Use sulfur or systemic fungicides in accordance with local recommendations during active disease periods; remove infected growth and improve hygiene.

Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.title: Cherry — Healthy
Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.description: Cherry plant shows no visible disease signs; foliage and fruits are normal.
Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.symptoms: No spots, discoloration, or deformities on leaves/fruit.
Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.prevention: Maintain orchard sanitary practices, monitor regularly, and ensure balanced nutrition and irrigation.
Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.remedy: None required; continue normal cultural practices.

Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.title: Corn (Maize) — Cercospora Gray Leaf Spot
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.description: Gray leaf spot (caused by Cercospora species) is a foliar disease that reduces photosynthetic area and can cause yield loss under favorable conditions (warm, humid).
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.symptoms: Small, rectangular tan to gray lesions between leaf veins that may coalesce into larger dead areas; premature leaf senescence.
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.prevention: Rotate crops, plant resistant hybrids, reduce residue by tillage or removal, and avoid monoculture where possible.
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.remedy: Apply foliar fungicides at key growth stages if disease thresholds are reached; manage residue and practice integrated disease management.

Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.title: Corn (Maize) — Common Rust
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.description: Common rust (Puccinia sorghi) causes orange-brown pustules on leaves and can reduce yield when severe. It thrives in humid conditions.
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.symptoms: Reddish to brown pustules (uredinia) on both leaf surfaces, which later turn black as spores mature.
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.prevention: Use resistant varieties, improve air flow, and avoid planting near infected fields.
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.remedy: Apply approved fungicides if disease pressure is high and monitor weather conditions favoring rust outbreaks.

Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.title: Corn (Maize) — Northern Leaf Blight
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.description: Northern leaf blight (Exserohilum turcicum) produces cigar-shaped lesions that can coalesce, reducing photosynthetic area and yield.
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.symptoms: Elongated gray-green to tan lesions often oriented parallel to leaf veins; heavy infections lead to extensive leaf death.
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.prevention: Plant resistant hybrids, use crop rotation, manage residue, and monitor for early signs.
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.remedy: Fungicide applications may be useful in high-pressure situations; integrate cultural controls to reduce inoculum.

Corn_(maize)___healthy.title: Corn (Maize) — Healthy
Corn_(maize)___healthy.description: No visible disease symptoms; plants appear vigorous and typical for the growth stage.
Corn_(maize)___healthy.symptoms: Green, intact leaves without lesions or discoloration.
Corn_(maize)___healthy.prevention: Use good agronomic practices: balanced fertilization, proper irrigation, and regular scouting.

Grape___Black_rot.title: Grape — Black Rot
Grape___Black_rot.description: Black rot (Guignardia bidwellii) is a destructive fungal disease causing fruit rot and leaf lesions. It is favored by warm, wet weather.
Grape___Black_rot.symptoms: Small brown leaf spots with black centers, round black fruit mummies, and sunken lesions on berries.
Grape___Black_rot.prevention: Sanitation: remove mummified fruit and infected canes, improve canopy airflow through pruning, and plant tolerant varieties.
Grape___Black_rot.remedy: Apply protectant and systemic fungicides as recommended, especially during bloom and pre-véraison periods; remove infected debris.

Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).title: Grape — Esca (Black Measles)
Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).description: Esca complex is a trunk and wood disease caused by several fungi and leads to decline, fruit spotting, and sometimes vine death over years.
Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).symptoms: Leaf interveinal chlorosis and necrosis, black spots on berries (black measles), and white rot in wood when cut open.
Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).prevention: Avoid excessive wounding, practice proper pruning techniques, and remove heavily infected vines to reduce spread.
Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).remedy: There is no cure; remove symptomatic wood, maintain vine vigor, and follow local management guidelines for trunk diseases.

Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.title: Grape — Leaf Blight (Isariopsis/Leaf Spot)
Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.description: Leaf blight diseases cause defoliation and reduce fruit quality. They are often favored by humid conditions.
Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.symptoms: Small brown to tan lesions on leaves that can enlarge and coalesce, leading to leaf loss.
Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.prevention: Improve canopy ventilation, remove infected leaves and debris, and avoid overhead irrigation in wet periods.
Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.remedy: Use fungicide programs and sanitation; follow local extension recommendations for timing and product selection.

Grape___healthy.title: Grape — Healthy
Grape___healthy.description: Vine shows no signs of disease and is in good health.
Grape___healthy.symptoms: Green leaves, normal clusters, no spotting or rot.
Grape___healthy.prevention: Continue routine vineyard care and monitoring.

Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).title: Orange — Huanglongbing (Citrus Greening)
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).description: Huanglongbing (HLB) is a bacterial disease (Candidatus Liberibacter) spread by psyllids. It is one of the most serious citrus diseases, causing fruit drop and tree decline.
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).symptoms: Yellowing of leaf veins, blotchy mottling of leaves, lopsided and bitter fruit, and overall decline of tree vigor.
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).prevention: Use certified disease-free nursery stock, control psyllid vectors, remove infected trees promptly, and monitor with testing.
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).remedy: No effective cure; management focuses on vector control, tree removal, and sanitation. Some nutritional programs may temporarily improve tree condition.

Peach___Bacterial_spot.title: Peach — Bacterial Spot
Peach___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot (Xanthomonas spp.) causes lesions on leaves, fruit, and twigs and can reduce fruit marketability.
Peach___Bacterial_spot.symptoms: Small dark water-soaked lesions on leaves and fruit that become scabby; premature defoliation in severe cases.
Peach___Bacterial_spot.prevention: Use disease-free nursery stock, prune to improve airflow, avoid overhead irrigation, and sanitize tools.
Peach___Bacterial_spot.remedy: Copper sprays can reduce severity when applied preventatively; follow local guidelines on timing and resistance management.

Peach___healthy.title: Peach — Healthy
Peach___healthy.description: No disease symptoms detected on peach; foliage and fruit appear normal.
Peach___healthy.symptoms: Green leaves, normal fruit set without lesions.
Peach___healthy.prevention: Maintain orchard hygiene, monitor regularly, and apply balanced nutrition.

Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.title: Bell Pepper — Bacterial Spot
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot (Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria) affects peppers causing spots on leaves and fruit and can reduce yields.
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.symptoms: Water-soaked lesions on leaves that become necrotic, scabby spots on fruit, and defoliation under heavy infection.
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.prevention: Use certified seed/transplants, rotate crops, avoid overhead irrigation, and practice sanitation.
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.remedy: Copper-based bactericides applied preventatively can reduce spread; remove heavily infected plants and practice good hygiene.

Pepper,_bell___healthy.title: Bell Pepper — Healthy
Pepper,_bell___healthy.description: Bell pepper plant shows no visible signs of disease; leaves and fruits are normal.
Pepper,_bell___healthy.symptoms: No lesions, normal leaf color and fruit development.
Pepper,_bell___healthy.prevention: Maintain good cultural practices and monitor plants regularly.

Potato___Early_blight.title: Potato — Early Blight
Potato___Early_blight.description: Early blight (Alternaria solani) causes concentric leaf spots and can defoliate plants, reducing tuber yield and quality.
Potato___Early_blight.symptoms: Brown to black concentric circular lesions on leaves, often on older foliage; tuber surface blemishes may also occur.
Potato___Early_blight.prevention: Use certified seed, rotate crops, avoid excess nitrogen, and remove infected residues.
Potato___Early_blight.remedy: Apply fungicides preventatively at disease-favoring conditions; practice sanitation and proper irrigation scheduling.

Potato___Late_blight.title: Potato — Late Blight
Potato___Late_blight.description: Late blight (Phytophthora infestans) is a devastating disease that can rapidly destroy foliage and tubers under cool, wet conditions.
Potato___Late_blight.symptoms: Dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves and stems that enlarge rapidly; white sporulation under humid conditions and rotting tubers.
Potato___Late_blight.prevention: Plant resistant cultivars, use certified seed, remove cull piles, and avoid overhead irrigation in humid climates.
Potato___Late_blight.remedy: Apply effective fungicides at first signs and under conducive weather; implement strict sanitation and destroy infected material.

Potato___healthy.title: Potato — Healthy
Potato___healthy.description: Potato crop shows healthy foliage and tuber development without disease symptoms.
Potato___healthy.symptoms: Green, intact leaves and healthy tubers without blemishes.
Potato___healthy.prevention: Follow recommended cultural practices: rotation, balanced fertilization, and proper irrigation.

Raspberry___healthy.title: Raspberry — Healthy
Raspberry___healthy.description: No visible disease symptoms on raspberry; canes and fruit appear healthy.
Raspberry___healthy.symptoms: Green leaves, normal fruiting without spots.
Raspberry___healthy.prevention: Maintain proper pruning, sanitation, and pest monitoring.

Soybean___healthy.title: Soybean — Healthy
Soybean___healthy.description: No disease signs detected on soybean plants; stands appear uniform and vigorous.
Soybean___healthy.symptoms: Unblemished leaves and normal pod formation.
Soybean___healthy.prevention: Use crop rotation, resistant varieties, and maintain soil fertility.

Squash___Powdery_mildew.title: Squash — Powdery Mildew
Squash___Powdery_mildew.description: Powdery mildew on squash is caused by several fungi producing white powdery growth on leaves and stems, leading to reduced vigor.
Squash___Powdery_mildew.symptoms: White to gray powdery patches on upper surfaces of leaves, yellowing, and leaf distortion.
Squash___Powdery_mildew.prevention: Plant resistant varieties, space plants for airflow, avoid excess nitrogen, and remove infected foliage.
Squash___Powdery_mildew.remedy: Apply sulfur or specific fungicides early; practice crop rotation and remove infected plant debris.

Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.title: Strawberry — Leaf Scorch
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.description: Leaf scorch is a bacterial or fungal condition that causes necrotic lesions and leaf death, reducing photosynthesis and yield.
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.symptoms: Dark brown leaf edges or spots that expand and cause leaf collapse; crowns and fruit may be affected in severe cases.
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.prevention: Use certified disease-free transplants, avoid overhead irrigation, and ensure good field drainage.
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.remedy: Remove and destroy infected plants; apply recommended fungicides/bactericides as advised by extension services.

Strawberry___healthy.title: Strawberry — Healthy
Strawberry___healthy.description: Strawberry plants are free of disease symptoms and producing healthy foliage and fruit.
Strawberry___healthy.symptoms: Green leaves and clean fruit with normal development.
Strawberry___healthy.prevention: Maintain good cultural practices, mulching, and regular monitoring.

Tomato___Bacterial_spot.title: Tomato — Bacterial Spot
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot (Xanthomonas spp.) causes small, dark lesions on leaves, stems, and fruit and can lead to defoliation and fruit blemishes.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.symptoms: Water-soaked spots on leaves that become angular and necrotic; small dark spots on fruit that reduce marketability.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.prevention: Use certified seed/ transplant material, practice crop rotation, remove infected debris, and control weeds.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.remedy: Copper-based sprays can reduce spread; combine with sanitation and resistant varieties when available.

Tomato___Early_blight.title: Tomato — Early Blight
Tomato___Early_blight.description: Early blight in tomato (Alternaria solani) causes concentric ring lesions on leaves and stems and may reduce yield if uncontrolled.
Tomato___Early_blight.symptoms: Dark brown circular lesions with concentric rings on foliage and fruit; plant vigor reduction with severe defoliation.
Tomato___Early_blight.prevention: Rotate crops, stake or trellis plants for airflow, avoid overhead watering, and remove lower leaves.
Tomato___Early_blight.remedy: Apply recommended fungicides, remove infected material, and use resistant cultivars when possible.

Tomato___Late_blight.title: Tomato — Late Blight
Tomato___Late_blight.description: Late blight (Phytophthora infestans) is a rapidly spreading disease that causes large necrotic lesions and can devastate crops in wet, cool weather.
Tomato___Late_blight.symptoms: Water-soaked brown lesions on leaves and stems, white sporulation under humid conditions, and rotting fruit/tubers.
Tomato___Late_blight.prevention: Use certified transplants, avoid overhead irrigation during cool, wet periods, and remove volunteer plants.
Tomato___Late_blight.remedy: Use timely fungicide applications and follow integrated disease management practices; remove and destroy heavily infected plants.

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.title: Tomato — Leaf Mold
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.description: Leaf mold (Cladosporium fulvum) is a fungal disease common in greenhouse and high-humidity conditions, producing yellow spots and olive mold on the underside.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.symptoms: Yellow spots on upper leaf surface and olive-brown mold on the underside; leaves may turn yellow and fall prematurely.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.prevention: Reduce humidity and improve ventilation, avoid overhead watering, and space plants to improve air flow.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.remedy: Apply appropriate fungicides and remove infected foliage; maintain good environmental controls in protected culture.

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.title: Tomato — Septoria Leaf Spot
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.description: Septoria leaf spot (Septoria lycopersici) is a common fungal disease causing numerous small circular spots on leaves and defoliation.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.symptoms: Small circular spots with dark brown margins and lighter centers on lower leaves; severe defoliation under wet conditions.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.prevention: Avoid overhead irrigation, remove infected debris, rotate crops, and space plants for airflow.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.remedy: Use fungicides when necessary and practice sanitation to reduce inoculum.

Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.title: Tomato — Spider Mites (Two-spotted Spider Mite)
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.description: Spider mites are tiny arachnids that suck plant sap, causing stippling, yellowing, and reduced vigor, especially under hot, dry conditions.
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.symptoms: Fine stippling on leaves, bronzing or yellowing, webbing in heavy infestations, and leaf drop.
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.prevention: Encourage natural predators (predatory mites), maintain adequate humidity, and avoid excessive dust or stress.
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.remedy: Use miticides or insecticidal soaps as appropriate; rotate control methods to avoid resistance and confirm target species before treatment.

Tomato___Target_Spot.title: Tomato — Target Spot
Tomato___Target_Spot.description: Target spot causes tan to brown lesions that may form concentric rings on leaves and can reduce photosynthetic area.
Tomato___Target_Spot.symptoms: Tan circular lesions with concentric rings on foliage that coalesce in severe infections causing defoliation.
Tomato___Target_Spot.prevention: Manage crop residues, improve air circulation, and avoid wet foliage for extended periods.
Tomato___Target_Spot.remedy: Apply recommended fungicides under high disease pressure; remove infected material and practice crop rotation.

Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.title: Tomato — Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus (TYLCV)
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.description: TYLCV is a viral disease transmitted by whiteflies that causes stunting, yellowing, and severely reduced yields. It is difficult to manage once established.
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.symptoms: Leaf curling and yellowing, stunted plants, reduced fruit set, and distorted foliage.
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.prevention: Use resistant varieties, control whitefly vectors with integrated pest management, and remove infected plants promptly.
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.remedy: No chemical cure for the virus; manage vectors and use cultural controls and resistant cultivars to limit spread.

Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.title: Tomato — Tomato Mosaic Virus (ToMV)
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.description: Tomato mosaic virus causes mottling and distortion of foliage and can reduce marketable yields. It spreads via infected seed, tools, and human handling.
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.symptoms: Mottled or mosaic leaf patterns, leaf curling or deformation, stunted growth, and reduced yield.
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.prevention: Use certified virus-free seed/stock, sanitize tools and hands, and remove infected plants.
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.remedy: No cure for viral infection; practice strict sanitation and use resistant varieties where available.

Tomato___healthy.title: Tomato — Healthy
Tomato___healthy.description: Tomato plant shows no signs of disease and exhibits normal leaf and fruit development.
Tomato___healthy.symptoms: Green leaves without spots, normal fruit formation, and no visible pests or pathogens.
Tomato___healthy.prevention: Maintain good sanitation, use resistant varieties, rotate crops, and monitor regularly.
Tomato___healthy.remedy: None required; continue good cultural practices.
